trial_identification.studytitle: Randomised trial of gratitude diaries for depressed patients using office based internet software.
trial_identification.scientifictitle: In primary care patients who are depressed with a PHQ score >9 does giving a gratitude diary in addition to an information sheet on depression result in lower PHQ scores after 4 months

interventions.interventions: The intervention group will be given a gratitude diary and an information sheet about depression. A gratitude diary is a book in which one is instructed to write down three things each day that they are grateful for and what they have done to cause that. This is done for one week then just once per week thereafter. The underlying theory is that it changes an individuals focus from what is not working to what is working. The duration of the study is four months
interventions.comparator: the control group will just be given the information sheet

primaryOutcome.outcome: PHQ-9 score and the Hopkins checklist for depression

secondaryOutcome.outcome: GAD- the GAD is an anxiety inventory which can be used to diagnose generalised anxiety disorder, panic disorder, post traumatic stress disorder and social anxiety disorder.

eligibility.exclusivecriteria: personality disorder bipolar disorder significant alcohol and drug condition dementia terminal illness

trial_design.concealment: We are using OfficeRCT software specifically developed for this trial. Once enrolled a message is sent to an offsite server which allocates either intervention or control on a random basis
trial_design.sequence: We are using OfficeRCT software specifically developed for this trial. Once enrolled a message is sent to an offsite server which allocates either intervention or control on a random basis
trial_design.designfeatures: Patients will be told there are two interventions and they will only be told of the one they are getting. At the end of the study they will be told of the other arm
